tweet: > If bitcoin were a currency, you could expect to be able to use it widely BTC (and even ETH) are accepted more widely than many very-small-country fiat currencies these days. So it's all relative.
I disagree with this page. It tries to argue that bitcoin is *not good as* a currency, but that's not the same thing as arguing it's *not* a currency. "Users are not protected" applies to cash too.

It would hurt confidence. But as you can see from Verge and Bitcoin Gold, it doesn't hurt that much. If the attacker does a sustained attack where they orphan other miners and mine empty blocks, that could really annihilate a coin. It would scare off all other miners.

Embrace the major algorithms and implement merged mining. So SHA/Scrypt/Ethash/CryptoNight/X11. If enough Bitcoin/Litecoin/Ethereum/Monero/Dash pools start merged mining DGB, then it becomes extremely hard to attack.

Here's a quick analysis to show that DigiByte's 5-algo system isn't more secure than Litecoin. To match the whole DigiByte network, it costs about $27MM and $1k/hr to attack. But since global hashrate for each algo dominates DigiByte's, it can likely all be rented for <$5000/hr.pic.twitter.com/tRsaVlNTt7

Sure, but why would an ongoing Twitter poll make it shady for me to reach out to chat with their CEO about a potential partnership? And plus, Litecoin was leading the poll when I reached out. Even if not, I don't see any problems.

Surprise! We don't bribe companies to support Litecoin. They do it because it's good for business. TapJets tried to contact XRP folks before I reached out. It's not my problem. And yes, they already supported BTC, so adding LTC is much simpler than XRP.

I would love to hear stories about what it was like to buy Bitcoin from that era. The OGs of Bitcoin.

During 2010, pre Mt Gox, alongside http://BitcoinMarket.com , there was also The Bitcoin Exchange in operation. I'd love to see their price data to reconstruct the full price chart 2009-2018, if anyone has it.

The famous Bitcoin Pizza Day was only 3 days earlier on 22 May 2010 when Laszlo Hanyecz paid 10,000 BTC for two Papa John's pizzas. 0.25 cents per BTC. Apparently the market rate was 0.41 cents per BTC. (via @ Investopedia)pic.twitter.com/hV2xPcjsRo

A trip down memory lane... The earliest # bitcoin price chart I've found is from http://bitcoincharts.com  of "Bitcoin Market". This was pre-MtGox. The "Cult of Bitcoin" is a paradox. It involves the veneration of ideals antithetical to cults like self sovereignty & rejection of authority. The "Cult of Bitcoin Cash," on the other hand, venerates Satoshi & is built on dogma via intepreting the sacred text of the whitepaper.

It's funny how people label me as a bitcoin maximalist. I'm not, but the longer I'm in this space and the more things I see, the more I feel I'm becoming one. So many fundamentally flawed projects and "thought leaders" getting praised for doing and saying stupid stuff. SMH
